Amsterdam Vallon.Action: Looks up to Vallon with worship and keen eyes shining with fear and excitement, indicating a trusting and sincere bond between them.
Carefully wraps the razor with care and respect, showing a sense of responsibility and reverence.
Does not intervene or react to disturbing sights in the hallway (faces peering, bodies stretched on path), indicating possible detachment or desensitization.
Carries ritual markings and leads a procession with armed and determined warriors, showing involvement in organized and purposeful group activity.
Participates in a cryptic and ominous ritual without hesitation or visible uncertainty.
Invites Monk Eastman to demonstrate his fighting skills before discussing payment, showing openness and willingness to engage fairly.
Encourages Monk Eastman to join the Natives and stand with them, extending an invitation to join forces.
Challenges Monk Eastman to show his skills before agreeing to payment, demonstrating confidence and practical judgment.
Successfully recruits a physically imposing and skilled fighter by evaluating him before acceptance, showing strategic thinking.
Leads his group out of a dilapidated building into a bleak environment with steady composure, indicating strong leadership and calm under pressure.
Rushes toward his father amid battle to protect him, uses a weapon to defend against an attacker.
Jumps back instinctively when his father’s eye springs open unexpectedly, showing alertness to a surprising event.
Shakes his dying father to revive him, demonstrating a refusal to give up and an attempt to take action in crisis.
Springs up aggressively to confront the approaching Rabbits who come to take his father’s body, showing protective instinct and assertiveness.
Remains in the center of the square unmoving and solitary, keeping vigil over his father, demonstrating emotional strength and resolve.
Silent acceptance of Happy Jack's gift of money for funeral expenses
Expresses wish for his father to be buried separately in fresh ground, facing east
Johnny runs away immediately after the Transvestite is struck, showing avoidance rather than confrontation or calm assessment.
Silently receives money from Happy Jack to support himself, showing acceptance and pragmatic survival.
Insists that his father be buried separately in fresh ground facing east, demonstrating respect, strong personal values, and a clear plan for honoring legacy.
Refuses Happy Jack's offer of help, insists on doing for himself.
Cries alone, revealing vulnerability and sorrow.
Attempts to pay for his father's burial with limited means, showing responsibility and respect.
Bulls his way through a crowd to retrieve his father's body from public display, struggles physically but insists on pulling the body out.
Commands Johnny to help with pulling the body and urges him insistently, showing both desperation and reliance on another.
Uses a plank to smash a window to get to the coffin, causing a scene and scattering the crowd.
Stays with the body despite approaching cops and physical assault.
Explains situation clearly and calmly to Bill The Butcher amidst chaos.
Flails wildly while being taken by cops.
Bites his lip to avoid crying out when beaten, forces a smile despite pain and frustration.
Repeatedly attempts to escape the orphanage despite harsh consequences.
Runs repeatedly from the orphanage guards despite being caught multiple times, showing persistence and strategic evasiveness.
Bites his lip to avoid crying out and forces a smile when beaten, showing emotional control and defiance.
Does not slow down until tackled by guards, demonstrating physical capability and determination.
Joins a risky boarding party during a foggy night, climbing rope ladders onto a larger ship despite uncertainty and danger.
Follows Shang's orders and moves cautiously across the deck, showing discipline and teamwork.
No direct individual action or leadership demonstrated; relies on others to navigate and respond to threats.
Not present or involved in the described scene; no action taken to influence outcome.
Grabs Shang to stop him from crying out and orders the boys to push off immediately, taking control of the situation decisively.
Directs the boat's movement with clear instructions to head straight out and then turn for the current, demonstrating navigational skill and leadership.
Shows casual disdain toward Shang's crew and challenges their claim to leadership, indicating confidence but also a potential misjudgment of social dynamics.
Promises to make up the cost of the body once in the city, showing a practical mindset and willingness to assume responsibility.
Throws his arm about Jenny in a proprietary way.
Questions the practice of giving part of stolen goods to the gang, expressing skepticism about the 'mob' system.
Stands his ground without fear when threatened with a sword cane by Shang.
Tells Johnny to find his own way, indicating a desire for independence and perhaps emotional distance.
Shrugs at Johnny's loyalty and keeps walking without encouraging or discouraging him, showing neutral tolerance.
Engages in light teasing by telling Johnny to shut up, but in a way that invites reflection, showing some familiarity and casual friendliness.
Questions Johnny about Tammany and expresses skepticism about joining their gang, favoring independence and working own schemes.
Studies Johnny's enthusiastic face thoughtfully, engaging in open dialogue.
Asks what Tammany is, showing lack of knowledge about significant local political powers.

Analyzes Johnny's enthusiastic description of Tammany and debates the merits of working with a large political gang versus running one’s own smaller schemes, showing thoughtful consideration and strategic thinking.
Carefully retrieves and inspects the money purse and pirate knife belonging to his father, showing care and respect.
Leaves Johnny behind and proceeds alone into the Old Brewery, showing independent and cautious behavior.
Does not interact with others, focusing on his personal quest.
Tears up floorboards and crawls through a short tunnel under the Brewery floor to retrieve a hidden money purse and pirate knife.
Carefully examines the retrieved items by candlelight, confirming their presence and significance.
Moves cautiously and watches carefully when emerging from the Brewery into the alley, assessing the situation with unknown men.
Presses himself close to the door to avoid detection by Shang, showing patience and stealth.
Waits and watches the interaction between Shang and the Second Man without intervening or making a mistake.
Watches Jenny with admiration and fascination, recognizing her skill as a pickpocket.
Flips the hangman a quarter and grabs the condemned man's coat for the silk handkerchief, quietly helping himself without confrontation.
Pushes his way through the crowd persistently to follow Jenny and keep track of events closely.
Pushes through crowd to find Jenny, attempts to get closer to her on the stage
Observes Jenny interacting intimately with another man without intervening or confronting
Pushes through the crowd determinedly to find Jenny and squeezes onto the stage in motion despite the packed situation.
Observes closely Jenny's subtle movements and the interactions between her and the Man, showing attention to detail.
Allows Jenny and the Man to continue their conversation without immediate intervention.
Perceives Jenny's secret pickpocketing despite the distractive and subtle nature of the act, demonstrating keen observation and awareness.
Approaches Jenny confidently, repeating a phrase similar to The Man's, showing social awareness and a measure of strategic interaction.
Hands Jenny the red silk scarf to help her keep more of her earnings, showing consideration for her well-being.
Watches silently as Jenny and Shang make their exchange, not intervening further.
Hands Jenny the red silk scarf, a symbol of cutting down the share paid to Shang; shows understanding of street dynamics and leverage.
Attempts to explain his intention to Jenny but is interrupted and struggles to immediately control the conversation.
Observes the interaction between Jenny and Shang quietly from the background, showing patience and caution.
Gives Jenny a red silk scarf, indicating an ability to provide or influence through intermediaries.
Challenges the unfairness of paying for free run of the Points and questions the legitimacy of Jack's watch possession.
Smiles when confirming his challenge about living day to day, showing a friendly and open demeanor.
Challenges Shang's claim about the watch and questions the fairness of paying for free run of the Points, showing critical thinking and confidence.
Reaches for the watch despite the tension and potential danger, escalating the conflict deliberately.
Steps in front of Jack confidently, throws a chair to stop Jack's attack, disarms him, and strikes him decisively.
Removes Jack's coat and carefully drapes it over Jenny's shoulders, showing tact and respect.
Says nothing when Shang confronts him about the red silk scarf, holding out his hand calmly rather than reacting defensively.
Calls out Shang's dishonesty calmly and strategically in front of the group, exposing his betrayal and rallying the mob to his side.
Challenges Shang to settle their dispute immediately and directly, demonstrating confidence and command over the situation.
Effectively gathers the mob’s support by clearly framing the choice between loyalty to Shang and himself, showing leadership and tactical awareness.
Almost smiling at Shang’s spiteful gesture but maintaining composure, showing emotional control and confidence.
Immediately renames the mob 'the Dead Rabbits' to establish a new identity and unify the group after Shang leaves.
Pulls Happy Jack's coat over Jenny to keep her warm in the chill air.
Waits for Jenny by the docks despite uncertainty, showing patience and trust.
Allows Jenny to leave when she indicates she wants to, respecting her agency.
States 'One way or another, I get what I want' with a smile after Jenny resists staying, implying persistence bordering on stubbornness.
Declares desire for exclusive and sincere love with Jenny, expressing that nobody means anything except one to the other.
Threatens Bill the Butcher with violent revenge, intending to take his 'one eye' and 'the rest of him, piece by small piece'.
Declares a clear intent to confront Bill the Butcher and expresses confidence that Bill will soon know about him.
Plans to raise a militia without concrete details shown in this excerpt, suggesting some strategic thought though not fully developed here.
Expresses a confident personal plan involving Jenny, showing emotional insight and determination.
Engages in a somewhat vague and uncertain emotional exchange with Jenny about love and meaning, reflecting some insecurity.
Analyzes political dynamics intelligently, recognizing the operational methods of Tammany and contrasting them with their own gang's ethics.
Challenges and questions Johnny's explanations and deals, showing critical thinking and caution.
Engages pragmatically with the realities of voter manipulation and politics, understanding the compromises involved.
Grabs a man and slams him down in a chair to force him to do his duty.
Barks orders to line up like soldiers, scaring and scattering Chinese gamblers.
Grabs two Chinese men by their pigtails and hurls them against the wall.
Shoves opium eaters out the door, rallying his group to round up people.
Engages cooperatively with Daniel Killoran, showing respect in their exchange.
Enjoys bantering with the bouncer, confidently asserts their presence.
Rejects Johnny's cautious tone with a somewhat dismissive 'The hell we do.'
No specific actions or statements by Amsterdam Vallon in this excerpt; focus is on Bill the Butcher's skill demonstration.
Addresses Bill the Butcher calmly and with respect, compliments his exhibition sincerely, smiles while speaking, initiates a drink to honor Bill and his father.
Speaks insultingly about others to Bill, calling them 'dogs' not worthy of him, using harsh language.
Sustains repeated violent blows without retaliating or reacting aggressively.
Appears passive and beaten, showing no hostility even when abused.
Is repeatedly struck and rendered barely sensible without resistance; body slack.
Endures physical assault silently and appears unable to act at a critical moment.
Fighting by brute instinct, flailing wildly, hits Jenny who tries to help him
Despite being beaten, does not lash out at others except in confusion and pain, assisted by friends in calming down
Starts flailing and fighting by brute instinct after being badly beaten, hits Jenny unintentionally.
Despite disoriented state, remains defiant and resists capture instead of surrendering quietly.
Declines a favor to avoid being beholden, expressing pride and independence but maintaining respect.
Proposes collaboration with Monk Eastman to strengthen the Dead Rabbits, showing openness and willingness to work together.
Expresses strong hostility toward the Natives, saying 'They won't have tongues left to speak.'
Welcomes everyone to the house of God, insists all are welcome regardless of background.
Acknowledges the possibility of conflict if certain guests arrive, showing realistic caution rather than overt hostility.
Tells Johnny he's tired and tries to postpone the fight, seeking a peaceful resolution.
Fights Johnny with determination but shows a pause of wonderment and sinks down beside him when Johnny falls.
Agrees to fight Johnny despite tiredness, matches Johnny blow for blow showing physical skill and resilience.
Appears confused and stunned when Johnny strikes unexpectedly, momentarily losing composure.
Uses physical advantage and skill to dominate parts of the fight but is slowed by injury and Johnny’s fury, indicating competent but not overwhelming dominance.
Asks Johnny what the fight is about, showing some attempt to understand motives before engaging.
Does not end the fight decisively; instead sinks down beside Johnny after the struggle, possibly indicating emotional distraction or fatigue.
After knocking out Johnny in a fight, he gently rubs water on Johnny's face to clean some blood and revives him, showing tenderness toward an opponent or friend.
Takes a punch from Johnny without dodging, possibly out of exhaustion or frustration, showing a level of tolerance.
Punches Johnny solidly to the jaw to end the fight, showing a necessary harshness but also control.
Fills pitchers of milk generously and manages a fair pricing strategy to help the community initially
Questions Jenny's charitable gesture with a sarcastic remark ('Except us. You opening a charity?')
Engages in a protective stance over Mother Joyce's establishment acknowledging the danger posed by the gang conflict
Promises Mother Joyce protection and loyalty by saying 'You only pay us. We see you safe from everyone.'
Observes Johnny intervening to help Emma Loss being hassled but does not intervene himself.
Jokes about offering Johnny as a bouncer, showing camaraderie and acceptance.
Acknowledges Johnny as 'a fast friend' despite differences, indicating tolerance and respect.
Admits to hitting Jenny and does not lie about it, showing honesty and taking responsibility.
Allows Jenny to tend to his bleeding nose and accepts her care.
Playful and intimate moment with Jenny, showing vulnerability and closeness in their relationship.
Threatens Jenny not to wake up without him, though stated as 'a declaration of love,' can be perceived as intimidating.
Accepts a solid punch without reacting violently; allows Jenny to tend to his bleeding nose and follows her instructions.
Engages in a direct and honest conversation about feelings and actions, showing emotional awareness and control.
Initiates intimacy with Jenny despite the recent conflict, displaying confidence and assertiveness.
Makes a threatening statement disguised as a declaration of love, demonstrating complexity but potential misjudgment in communication.
Reacts with surprise and gratitude upon receiving a gift from Jenny, showing appreciation and some trust despite suspicion.
Watches Jenny enter an unfamiliar house with fascination and quiet observance, showing openness and curiosity rather than suspicion or hostility.
Surprised and suspicious but shows gratitude when given the diamond ring by Jenny.
Follows Jenny into an unfamiliar wealthy neighborhood, showing curiosity and a willingness to explore beyond his usual environment.
Observes quietly through the window, taking in the unfamiliar upper-class lifestyle and behavior with fascination and caution.
Expresses doubt and disbelief about Jenny's plan and the situation (e.g., telling Jenny she is 'off her head').
Slides a ring onto Jenny's finger, she kisses him.
Holds up a gold cross to Jenny, then slips it into his pocket without answering her question.
Cautiously asks Jenny if they can trust her mother.
Slips a gold cross into his pocket without answering Jenny's question and continues digging, showing focus and purposeful behavior.
Questions Jenny skeptically: 'Are you sure we can trust your mother?,' indicating caution and critical thinking.
Places a gold cross at his father's grave, speaks with sincerity about his feelings and the unfinished nature of his revenge.
Shares a private moment with Jenny, invites her to meet his father, showing trust and openness.
Expresses intense personal pain and guilt over his father's death, revealing emotional depth and vulnerability.
Quietly retrieves the gold cross from his coat pocket and places it carefully at his father's grave, showing deliberate and meaningful behavior.
Engages in a calm, reflective conversation with Jenny about his father's death and his own role, demonstrating emotional control and clarity.
Refuses to finish the gravestone inscription until his goal of vengeance or resolution is complete, showing patience and a strategic mindset.
Expresses intense emotional experience related to his father's death, which could suggest potential vulnerability or fixation but also indicates deep personal motivation.
Declares his intent to kill Bill to free himself from the past, showing decisiveness and clarity of purpose.
Explains a unified vision for the Dead Rabbits, integrating individual and group goals strategically.
Leverages the gang’s collective action to gain power and profit, demonstrating strategic thinking and leadership.
Refers to bringing glory to the gang as a justification for his and his father's actions, reflecting motivation but potential personal bias or abstraction.
Yells encouragingly at prizefighters to finish the fight quickly, showing engagement and enthusiasm.
Appears confident and decisive by springing to his feet and ordering prizefighters to finish the fight quickly.
Recognizes the right time for action instinctively as referenced in his voiceover narrations.
Engages in provocative banter challenging the Native American fighters and shows eagerness for confrontation
Acknowledges the importance of the political power balance in New York (Tammany vs Dead Rabbits) in a practical, strategic way
Waves back Rabbits to prevent escalation after the fight, showing restraint toward his own group.
Jumps into the fray and pushes away attacking Natives, protecting others.
Whispers to Barnum to calm the crowd and promote a duel for honor, not money, emphasizing justice.
Challenges the notion of strength by questioning Johnny, showing critical judgment rather than blind aggression.

Maintains composure despite crowd excitement and tension
Challenges Bill the Butcher directly to a duel on Bill's terms, demonstrating confidence and initiative.
Maintains composure and recalls past encounters with Bill the Butcher intelligently during the handshake moment.
Shows belief that the right moment has come to confront Bill the Butcher, indicating situational awareness.
States clearly that the day will be one of honor with no pickpockets or lush-rollers, showing foresight and leadership in maintaining order during the event.

Engages in strategic planning during the war council, contributing to the negotiations about profit sharing and event location, demonstrating negotiation skills and involvement in leadership decisions.
Fails to prevent the killing of Sheeny Mike, a member of their own gang, raising questions about his control or influence over events and allies.
Argues passionately with Johnny about loyalty and the killing, showing emotional investment but perhaps lacking influence to change outcomes.
Does not take direct action against Johnny immediately after Mike’s death, which could indicate hesitance or strategic patience.
Analyzes the chaotic situation calmly from a vantage point and makes strategic observations about the rioters' motives and leadership.
Engages in a thoughtful conversation with Jenny, questioning the influences on people's beliefs and motivations, showing insight and critical thinking.
Acknowledges his own role honestly when confronted by Jenny about his loyalty and deception, which may indicate reliability or accountability.
Shows some naivety or emotional bias in evaluating the rioters as lacking purpose, which could underestimate a complex social conflict.
Addresses his gang calmly, proposes a plan to take advantage of the riots for their own benefit rather than fighting impulsively.
Greets Jenny warmly, acknowledges her return, and includes her in the plan without hesitation.
Shows strategic leadership and inclusiveness but is focused on conflict and looting, indicating pragmatic but potentially exploitative intentions.
Leads Johnny to a private corner to talk openly despite suspicion.
Questions Johnny directly and with some suspicion if he is spying.
Prepares weapons for a scheme, showing readiness for conflict, not notably warm.
Prepares a brace of pistols for the next day's scheme, showing readiness and planning.
Leads Johnny off to a private, shadowy corner to talk, demonstrating awareness and control over the situation.
Responds to Johnny's accusations with calm defiance and evasiveness ('Am I now? Why do you think that?'), indicating strategic thinking.
Fails to reveal or confirm plans openly even under suspicion, showing discretion and discipline.
Listens to Johnny's warning about Tweed's plan and responds calmly, showing willingness to consider the information.
Responds coldly and somewhat dismissively to Johnny's concerns, questioning the loyalty of Tweed's men and showing distrust.
Invites Johnny to stay if he believes Amsterdam's claim that he will lose nothing, showing a guarded openness.
Masks his feelings with resolve and focus rather than showing overt friendliness or warmth during tense moments.
Walks through enemy camp silently despite provocation, restrains temper.
Rallies Dead Rabbits gang, including Jenny and others, leading them unitedly.
Remembers past fights alongside his father silently, showing reflection.
Kicks down door to lead gang out boldly.

Rallies his entire gang effectively, inspiring unity and coordinated action.
Leads the gang through a dangerous and confusing tunnel system skillfully.
Kicks down the door symbolizing decisive leadership, mirroring legendary predecessors.
Leads the group against the Armory with determination and strategic intent.
Interacts pragmatically with rioters, showing focus on the conflict rather than personal connection.
Urgently demands the Guards open the doors to help wounded comrades.
Shoots a Guard immediately after friendly exchange to take control of the armory.
Commands the guards to open the doors to the Armory for the wounded Dead Rabbits and negotiates access under pressure.
Shoots a guard immediately after being let in, demonstrating tactical ruthlessness and decisiveness.
Shouts orders to move fast to secure as much as possible before militia arrives, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Calmly confronts Bill the Butcher at the Armory, negotiates terms rather than resorting to violence.
Keeps control of the situation while others are confused or ready to fire, demonstrating poise and strategic thinking.
Acknowledges the tension and risks ('You want to get out alive?') indicating awareness of stakes and consequences.
Observes the situation intently and gives clear, tactical orders to his gang to provide cover.
Despite issuing orders, the gang hesitates to act due to surprise and confusion.

Questions Bill the Butcher about whose gang will emerge, showing awareness and initiative in a chaotic combat situation.

Engages with Bill the Butcher calmly and confidently in the midst of battle, indicating composure under pressure.

Pulls Jenny away from retrieving her swag and from danger just before a massive explosion.

Struggles to keep up with his father as they walk down the corridor.
Responds to Shang Draper's question patiently and includes him in the group, indicating openness and trustworthiness.
Leads men and women from the Brewery across a plank bridge, showing leadership but no clear indication of warmth or coldness.
Confidently leads a group across a plank bridge, indicating leadership and control over the crowd.
Responds quickly and confidently to Shang's question about the fight, showing awareness and clarity of the situation.

Does not engage in unnecessary exposition or self-doubt, maintaining a calm demeanor in a tense environment.

Draws first blood in a brutal gang fight, impaling a man to kill.

RUSHES forward to help his father in the fight, showing concern and protective instinct.
Hysterically rushes at Bill the Butcher after his father is stabbed.

Reacting immediately to try to save or comfort his father, showing presence of mind under pressure.

Reacting with shock and stepping back when his father’s eye opens unexpectedly.

Insists on paying more than the offered amount for his father's burial, refusing to accept partial payment and showing determination to honor his father properly.
Cries alone, showing vulnerability and emotional openness in private.
Stares down Happy Jack, signaling confidence and self-reliance by refusing his offer of help.
Uses a plank like a battering ram to smash a window and rescue his father's body despite crowd opposition.

Stays with the body of his father as the cops close in, enduring physical blows.

Answers jailer's questions calmly and concisely despite the intimidating situation.
Shows no overt signs of panic or confusion during the booking process in prison.

Shows no willingness to put away conflict or defer confrontation despite warnings about consequences.

Demonstrates courage and determination as noted by Killoran describing him having 'sand' and 'heart' to carry the feud forward

Looks at the houses with wonder but tries to make it casual.

Physically attacks the Two Gents without warning to protect Jenny and assert control.
Offers that those who cannot pay rent can join the gang and have access to the best rooms.
Takes control of a tense situation by negotiating then suddenly overpowering two opponents with swift, decisive action using his rifle butt.
Confidently asserts leadership by ordering the removal of defeated enemies and reorganizing the space to favor his group.
Dismisses interruptions from opponents to maintain control of the negotiation/confrontation.
Kneels beside Jenny to help dig at the grave with stones and bones.
Reaches inside Jenny's chest of stolen goods and slips a ring onto her dirt-covered finger.
Jokes about Jenny trusting him with her treasure, engaging in friendly banter.
Hands Jenny a candle promptly and aids her in digging at the grave when asked.
Accepts trust by handling Jenny's treasure box carefully and respectfully.
States confidently that the Dead Rabbits have the Natives within range and it's time to 'squeeze the trigger,' indicating strategic awareness and readiness to act decisively.

Engages in a tense conversation about political alliances and power dynamics, showing understanding of complex social forces but appears somewhat dismissive of warnings about consequences, which may be shortsighted.
Waves off his supporters from rushing the ring to prevent further chaos.
Judges the strength of the fighter and confidently declares it not strong.
Jumps into the fray to push away attackers, showing physical capability and bravery.
Whispers instructions to Barnum to control the crowd and announce a duel, showing strategic thinking.
Interrupts and emphasizes the seriousness of the duel, controlling the narrative.
Stands with Jenny watching as Sheeny Mike is carried off, showing a composed presence but not intervening.
Stands silently watching the aftermath of Sheeny Mike’s accident without intervening.
Mother Joyce vouches for Amsterdam's youth and hunger; others expect him to succeed.
Insists he doesn't care about what others want, only about protecting the Points, showing loyalty to his community.
Rejects Jenny's offer to leave, stating he must stay and continue fighting for a cause, showing stubbornness but also commitment.
Expresses steadfast determination to protect the Points and his own goals despite external pressures.
Refuses to abandon the fight or follow Jenny, showing focus but potentially missing opportunity for alliance.
Proposes the audacious plan to take the banks and government funds, inspiring reluctant gang members to follow him despite their fear and uncertainty.
Proposes an ambitious, audacious plan to take the government banks, demonstrating strategic vision and inspiring reluctant followers to unite behind him.
Processes new, complex intelligence about an imminent threat against Bill the Butcher and the Armory, showing he is alert and assimilating information.
Responds with skepticism initially but then listens carefully to Johnny's warning, indicating cautious judgment and openness.
Declares confidence in not losing anything despite the threat, demonstrating resolve and mental toughness.
Invites Johnny to stay if he trusts him, showing some control over the situation and interpersonal interactions.
Facial expression trying to work out angles and new information, indicating analytic thinking but also some uncertainty.
Surrounded at the Natives' hideout, seemingly trapped but facing the situation with unblinking resolve, showing courage but possible vulnerability.
